title: woman-found-nearly-three-times-drink-driving-limit
story: Jacqueline Johnstone, of St Germains Terrace, was caught drink-driving at Gilbert Avenue in North Berwick.Johnstone, , was found to have mg of alcohol in ml of breath during the incident ndash the legal limit is mg.She appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court, where she pleaded guilty to the offence, which took place on May .Sherf Pamela Bowman banned Johnstone from driving for  months and fined her pound.She was allowed to take part in a drink-driving rehabilitation scheme which could reduce her ban by a quarter.

title: north-berwick-high-school-roll-set-top-1-000-extension-planned
story: The school, which welcomes pupils from the surrounding villages as well as North Berwick, currently has a school roll of .However, that figure is expected to increase, with the town continuing to grow and the school set to become the fourth secondary school in the county with more than , pupils.Three extensions ndash in ,  and  ndash have already been carried out on the school to accommodate the growth of the town.Now, the proposed extension would cater for a school roll of up to ,.Plans submitted to East Lothian Council note: ldquoThe completed building will provide state-of-the-art teaching and social space facilities in line with the clientrsquos brief as well as promoting energy efficiency and offering facilities which signal the high value placed on learning at North Berwick High School.ldquoThe project is to reflect the standards commensurate with a modern school facility and provide a high-quality environment that will inspire both staff and young people to achieve their full potential.The proposed extension would occupy an area to the south-west of the existing buildings, bordered by the synthetic pitch and the site boundary with the schoolrsquos neighbours Law Primary School.The document states: ldquoThe location of the proposed extension will offer views out over the sports pitches and towards North Berwick Law.The ground floor of the three-storey extension will become home to the home economics department, with a shared social and exhibition space.Social sciences will be based on the first floor, with the languages department on the second floor and ldquolarge shared breakout spaces at the heart of the floorplan.The plans from Innovate East Lothian Ltd, which is acting on behalf of East Lothian Council, could go before the local authorityrsquos planning committee later this year.Currently, Dunbar Grammar School , Musselburgh Grammar Schooland Ross High Schoolin Tranent all have more than , pupils.

title: council-remove-recycling-wheelie-bins-contamination
story: East Lothian Council is one of the few local authorities in Scotland to retain recycling boxes for most of its households and has a  per cent recycling rate ndash higher than the national average.However, Tom Reid, the councilrsquos head of infrastructure, revealed that it had rolled out , communal recycling bins in small communities and densely populated streets.But, he said, the result had been a much higher contamination level in the recycled waste which suggested thatbins were rolled out across the county it could cost the council up to poundmillion. The bins, first used in , are now being removed by the council and replaced with inidual boxes.Mr Reid told a meeting of the councilrsquos policy and performance review committee that the bins had not been a success.Councillor Gordon Mackett asked why wheelie bins could not be used, saying he was told by people they ldquowould recycle morethey had wheelie bins.But Mr Reid said: ldquoUsing the boxes produces a higher quality of recycling waste and we currently sell it for up to pound,.ldquoWe have , wheelie bins out there and the result has been a disappointing  to  per cent contamination.ldquoIf we moved to wheelie bins we would have to pay out between poundmillion to poundmillion to decontaminate the materials.A council spokesperson said the recycling bins had already been removed from some parts of the county, with the rest expected to be replaced by boxes in the near future.

title: stars-music-sport-tv-head-east-lothian-scottish-open-pro-am
story: The Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open gets under way next Thursday , with some of the worldrsquos top golfers looking to gain momentum heading into The Open.Twenty-four hours before competition gets under way, Tartan Wednesday s to the competition, along with the Pro-Am tournament.Fans are encouraged to join players and celebrities by donning tartan in aid of the tournament charities: My Namersquo Doddie Foundation, Leuchie House and the European Tour Foundation.Television presenters Dan Walker and Naga Munchetty, who regularly share the sofa on BBC Breakfast, will be joined by TV personality and regular Hero Challenge host Vernon Kay.Frontman for Scottish rock band Twin Atlantic Sam McTrusty is joined by comedian-turned-radio presenter Fred MacAulay and talkSPORT presenter Georgie Bingham.Staying in sport, Winter Olympian Eve Muirhead will also join what promises to be a fun day out on the golf course.In a battle of the Irish boy bands, Boyzone singer Keith Duffy and singer-songwriter and former Westle vocalist Brian McFadden will also tee it up.Former Scotland and British Lions lock forward Doddie Weir revealed in June  that he had been diagnosed with motor neurone disease. In November that year, he and his trustees launched the My Namersquo Doddie Foundation to raise funds to aid research into the causes of motor neurone disease and investigate potential cures.Leuchie House, near North Berwick, is Scotlandrsquos only dedicated respite centre and offers caring respite breaks to people with long-term neurological conditions, including motor neurone disease.By providing the care they need, Leuchie is able to support people with many dferent conditions to have fulfilling, revitalising breaks, while giving their carers time away from caring.The two charities joined the European Tour Foundation ndash which works with charities, players, governing bodies and partners to ensure a lasting legacy in the countries where the European Tour plays ndash as official charity partners of the Scottish Open in , and will once again benefit from a range of fundraising activities throughout tournament week, including Tartan Wednesday.The Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open is being played for the first time at The Renaissance Club, which was founded in  and nestles on  picturesque acres along the Firth of Forth. Tickets for the Pro-Am are pound for adults and pound for juniors.

title: kind-pupils-help-raise-money-beach-wheelchairs-project
story: Youngsters at The Compass School collected an impressive pound. through an enterprise sale at the Haddington school, with the money going to North Berwick-based Beach Wheelchairs.The schoolrsquos pupil council identied the good cause as one of the three main charities to support throughout the year.Beach wheelchairs enable people with disabilities to access the beach through using specially designed wheelchairs created to travel over the sand and even into the water.The scheme was first set up in  and, since then, similar facilities have been established in Portobello and at Seton Sands.The enterprise sale, which took place before the end of the schoolrsquos term, saw children designing and making a range of dferent items, from artwork to baking and from origami creations to practical items to use at home.The sale followed on from a successful Swimathon earlier this year, with youngsters ing in to raise funds for WaterAid.Mark Becher, headmaster at the school on West Road, was proud of the pupils.He said: ldquoI was delighted when the children of our pupil council chose Beach Wheelchairs as one of the principle charities they would be supporting this year.ldquoThe charity does so much fantastic work and has opened up the beautul beaches of East Lothian for those who previously had very restricted access or none at all. The children greatly enjoyed creating and making for the enterprise sale, which saw a vast range of goods for sale.ldquoTo achieve this total is testament to their efforts and the generosity of all those who supported them.ldquoWe would like to thank everyone who assisted the children in this very successful initiative.Last week, a group of staff and children from the pupil council visited Melanie Kay at Beach Wheelchairsrsquo facility in North Berwick.The children had the opportunity to view all of the wheelchairs and to meet with a family who had travelled from the west of Scotland in order to use a wheelchair.The pupils spoke to the family about the benefits of the charity and they all observed the importance of these chairs first-hand.

title: princess-anne-makes-special-visit-leuchie-house
story: EAST Lothian played host to a distinguished guest as the Princess Royal made a special visit to the county.Her Royal Highness Princess Anne paid a visit to Leuchie House, the respite care centre near North Berwick which offers respite breaks for people with a iety of long-term conditions as well as their carers, last Thursday.The Princess Royal previously visited Leuchie in  and launched the lsquoLeuchie Forever Fundrsquo, a new fundraising initiative for the charity, of which she became patron. She also visited in .On her latest visit, the Princess ndash who was described as a ldquolovely lassie by one guest ndash was greeted by Mark Bevan, chief executive, and Bob Brannan, chair of the fund, and taken to meet Leuchiersquos guests, staff, supporters, patrons and trustees.The meeting was held in Leuchiersquos lounge, with a series of paintings hanging on the walls created by Rachel Mylne, who had turned  two days prior to the royal visit.Money raised by the Leuchie Forever Fund had allowed the lounge to be redecorated, and when hanging the paintings on the wall a signature from the s, a mark from a previous painter, was discovered.On her arrival at Leuchie, Princess Anne first met some of the guests and their carers. She asked questions including ldquoHow did you find out about this place  and ldquoHow long have you been coming here  She listened to their stories and the dference Leuchie had made in their lives.Moving on to the trustees, donors and patrons, she was interested in hearing how they had discovered Leuchie and how they had become involved in the charity.Among those present was Scottish rugby legend Gavin Hastings, who is also a patron of Leuchie.Describing his involvement in the charity, he said: ldquoItrsquos a great place to come along and itrsquos great to support the work that they do here because they do such great work ndash not just here in Leuchie but all over Scotland.After meeting the Princess, many praised her humour and willingness to take the time and talk to everyone, listening to their stories. Others mentioned how hardworking and well-briefed she was and how much she knew about Leuchie.Regular guest Iain Elder described the Princess as ldquoa lovely lassie, while others praised her interest and passion for the charity.Jim Maxwell, who is the primary carer for we Jane, a guest at Leuchie, said of his conversation with the Princess: ldquoShe asked where we lived and how we managed to find Leuchie House. I told her as a carer it is very important for the both of us to come here.ldquoShe really took the time to speak to us and hear our story.Afterwards, some of the guests gave a speech where they explained how much Leuchie House had helped them.Alex MacCarthy-Morrogh has multiple sclerosis and visits Leuchie every Tuesday as a day guest. As well as attending physio and fitness classes, which he describes as essential for his physical and mental wellbeing, he talks to fellow guests to keep them company.He said: ldquoI come here to help myself and to give my we a break and give her some freedom. Me being here, she knows Irsquom safe which is very important to me.ldquoThis place is important to the people here, therersquos no other place like it. They treat you like a person and see you beyond the wheelchair.His we Susie said: ldquoItrsquos great when Alex comes here. Falling is his biggest concern and I donrsquot worry he is going to fall when he is here. Him being safe is so important to me and they really look after him and everyone here.Mairi OrsquoKeefe, patron and former chief executive of Leuchie House, said: ldquoPrincess Anne loves the work we do here and the respiratory things that we do everyone gets physio and everyone gets a respiratory assessment. She also sees what it does for the guests.ldquoShe really cares about Leuchie.A tour of Leuchie followed, with Princess Anne meeting one volunteer who wrote the calligraphy on the invites and who gave the Princess a humorous wink.When speaking to the dieticians, Princess Anne expressed how dficult it must be to keep up with a iety of dferent diets.She took an interest in one, a soon-to-be graduate, asking about her experience in Leuchie in relation to her studies and saying: ldquoYoursquove probably come across more diets here than on your course!Her tour led on to the art room, while in the TV room Princess Anne met one guest who had been coming to Leuchie since , jokingly saying: ldquoYoursquore keeping them on their toes!The Princess was taken into a further lounge and met a man taking part in a virtual reality experience.When she noticed he was in London, she said: ldquoI know London very well. She was told he caught a whale earlier ndash ldquonot in the Thames, I hope, she replied.Mark Bevan, chief executive of Leuchie, said: ldquoWe were thrilled to welcome HRH The Princess Royal, and patron of the Leuchie Forever Fund, to Leuchie House once again and for her to meet and thank our many supporters.ldquoShe saw first-hand the importance of providing quality respite to our guests and their carers.ldquoThe visit was a wonderful experience for our guests and colleagues who were able to spend time with Her Royal Highness. She spoke to them about their experiences and the dference that spending time at Leuchie makes to their lives and those of their carers.Bob Brannan, chairman of the Leuchie Forever Fund, said: ldquoThe Princess has taken time since becoming our patron three years ago to really understand Leuchie.ldquoToday as on previous occasions, she has used this understanding to encourage our many generous supporters to ensure Leuchie can continue to develop and provide such a great service to so many people across Scotland for years to come.As the visit came to an end, the Princess signed the visitorsrsquo book and was presented flowers and a card by Rachel Mylne, who said: ldquoThank you for all your hard work, we are very grateful. Leuchie is a wonderful place, will you try and keep it going Princess Anne replied: ldquoI will definitely try my best.

title: thousands-expected-attend-aberdeen-standard-investments-scottish-open-renaissance-club
story: Thousands of fans are expected to flock to East Lothianrsquos Golf Coast between today and Sunday as the competition heats up.Among those taking part are four-time Major winners Rory McIlroy and Ernie Els, Scotlandrsquos last Major champion Paul Lawrie and former world number one Justin Thomas.Brandon Stone, who won the tournament at nearby Gullane Golf Club  months ago, is joined by Rickie Fowler, who lted the title at the same club in .Action gets under way at .am with Joakim Lagergren, Oliver Wilson and Scott Henry taking to the course.North Berwickrsquos Grant Forrest also has an early start as his bid for the title begins at .am alongside Matthieu Pavon and Andy Sullivan.Former Dunbar Grammar School pupil David Drysdale tees off at .pm alongside Andrew Johnston and Erik Van Rooyen, with McIlroy and Fowler playing alongside Robert MacIntyre from .pm.The final round of the day tees off at .pm with Steven Brown, Ben Evans and Justin Walters taking to the course.The Pro-Am was played at the course yesterday .

title: new-homes-over-60s-longniddry-welcomed
story: East Lothian Council gave the go-ahead for nearly  new houses in three separate applications to its planning committee.One application for four houses and  flats revealed that all its units would be for older people.The housing, which is on land identied for potentially having up to  new homes on it, to the south of Longniddry, will be taken by Castle Rock Edin Housing Association once built.A planning application before the committee revealed: ldquoAll of the residential units would be for independent living for people aged over  years.The flats will mainly be in two-storey buildings, with one three-storey building and four bungalows which will be built around a courtyard-style quadrangle.Two additional applications included one for  houses and  flats, all of which will be for private sale, and another for  houses and  flats, of which only two houses and eight flats will be affordable.Places for People, which is overseeing the over-s housing and  private properties, welcomed the decision as the ldquofirst phase in the Longniddry South development.Willie Lockhart, Places for People interim director of development for Scotland, said: ldquoWe are delighted to have the go-ahead to begin building at Longniddry. It promises to be a truly special development offering benefits to both new and existing residents of the village.The layout of the development, on land owned by the Wemyss and March Estate, sees housing designed by architect Ben Pentreath to reflect traditional East Lothian homes, and the committee was shown a walkthrough video depicting what the streets will look like.Ward councillor Lachlan Bruce said: ldquoI welcome the decision to provide affordable housing for over-s in Longniddry.ldquoIt is an issue for people wanting to downsize from their properties which are then freed up for families who want to move in.Representatives of Longniddry Community Council attended the meeting to raise concerns about some of the infrastructure surrounding the new housing. But they told the committee they had no objections to the development itself.Councillor Norman Hampshire, planning convenor, encouraged the community council to contact the local authority with any concerns about issues during the development of the new housing.And council leader Willie Innes praised the members of the community council for attending.He said: ldquoThe community council raise valid concern which will need to be addressed by the developers. They are not opposing it in principle and we want to work with the community to manage the process.He added: ldquoI think this development is something special and something dferent and will make a positive impact on Longniddry and East Lothian.Rock Feilding-Mellen, from Socially Conscious Capital, which worked with the landowners to develop a masterplan for the entire site, welcomed the plansrsquo approval.He said: ldquoWe are thrilled that Zero C can now start building these much-needed new homes and turning our carefully designed masterplan and design code into a beautul st-century extension to Longniddry.ldquoWe trust that residents and members of the wider community who contributed throughout the many consultations will feel that their time and effort has paid off when they finally get to see the results.

title: knox-academy-half-marathon-team-raise-2-000
story: Eleven S pupils were joined by half a dozen members of staff at the Edinburgh Marathon Festivalrsquos half-marathon start line.The Knox Academy group all donned special t-shirts highlighting they were running for East Lothian Special Needs Playscheme .The school has formed a strong bond with the charity, which provides full-day playschemes during school holidays for children aged five to  with a wide range of special needs disabilities, and previously secured pound, for the good cause through a Youth Philanthropy Initiativescheme.Lana Borwick, PE teacher, was among those taking part.She said: ldquoThere was a real sense of community around the event.ldquoAll the participants took to the lsquoPink Penrsquo to give each other final words of support and encouragement before the early start on the day.ldquoAlmost all of the Knox Academy runners were making their half marathon debut which was a real test of their commitment to training and they didnrsquot disappoint, with everyone completing the challenge despite the poor weather conditions ndash some in remarkable times!ldquoIt was a wonderful occasion and we are all very proud of what wersquove managed to achieve together, ultimately impacting on the opportunities that the playscheme can continue to provide to youngsters in our community.ldquoIt was great also to see so many people brave the weather to come out and cheer us on, both from our school community and from the Playscheme, which really helped as the legs started to tire!ldquoEvents like this serve as a fantastic reminder to us of the commitment, enthusiasm and drive that our young people have to make a dference in society.Joining Miss Borwick, who completed the .-mile course in a time of :., at the finish line were pupils Matthew Black , Dylan Brotherston , Isabelle Bowen , Elliot Cochrane , Harry Cunningham , Hana Elder , Adam Fairgrieve , Mateusz Juchniewicz , Max Leveque , Daniel Mackinnonand Lauren Taylor , as well as Robert Flood, Susanne Fox, Thomas Salkeld, Suzie Stewart and Alex Redford .Kirsty Milne of ELSNP was ldquoblown away by the support.She said: ldquoThe team have signicantly raised our charityrsquos profile by embarking on such a tremendous fundraiser and we are extremely thankful to them for the incredible amount raised.ldquoWe have strengthened links with Knox Academy over the years, with many of their pupils past and present volunteering at or attending our playscheme and youth club provisions and it is amazing to see the school uniting to support our local cause.ldquoWe cannot thank the runners enough for their incredible efforts and for raising such a large sum of money.ldquoOur playschemes will be running for the full six weeks of the summer break and, thanks to the generous donations from the Edinburgh Marathon Festival, we will be able to offer many fun trips and outings to those attending.ldquoThere is something really special about seeing local young people coming together to support their peers and we are thankful to all at Knox Academy for their support.

title: bid-third-pharmacy-tranent-turned
story: The application was presented to the Pharmacy Practice Committee , which decided that the town was already suitably served by its current pharmacies.The committee also stated that there was too long a wait between the Consultation Analyst Reportand the hearing as over a year had passed, which it felt rendered the findings out of date.Representatives from the current Tranent pharmacies ndash Lloyds Pharmacy and Well Tranent, both on High Street ndash were present at the committee hearing and both claimed that they had already addressed any issues that were raised in the consultation and therefore problems raised by the CAR were no longer applicable.There was also a question over whether the premises planned for the new pharmacy at  Bridge Street would be large enough to support the planned two consultation rooms and dispensary area, which the committee felt raised the issue of whether appropriate confidentiality was possible.Letters of support for the pharmacy were submitted by Tranent and Elphinstone Community Council and ward councillor Kenny McLeod among others however, the committee felt that none of these letters ldquospecied needs which were currently not being met.Pharmacy applicant Niamh Morrison visited the community council to thank members for their support over the process and to assure them that she would be launching an appeal.She said: ldquoI am of course very disappointed.ldquoI really believe that this community needs this, and I have developed a real soft spot for the area.ldquoThe appeal process unfortunately wonrsquot be quick, it could take years.ldquoI just wanted to thank you all for the support that you have given us.The rejection comes not long after Tranent Medical Practice announced that it would be suspending advanced appointments due to a shortage of GPrsquos.Robert McNeill, a member of the community council, said: ldquoFrom a personal point of view, Irsquom very disappointed.ldquoTranent surgery is not unique in its problems and the pharmacy could have added extra services within the community.David Forrest, chairman of the community council added with regards the letter that the group had drafted to support the application: ldquoThe letters that we wrote came from the heart, we really feel that this was what was best for our community.ldquoWe are incredibly disappointed with the decision, and fully support Niamh in her appeal.ldquoWe will be writing to our local MP and MSP to register our frustration at the situation.ldquoThe decision is very short-sighted.The decision comes as planning permission in principle has been approved for  houses at Windygoul South, though the committee determined that both Lloyds and Well Tranent were able to increase capacity should ldquoproposed housebuilding occur locally.Ward councillor Kenny McLeod said: ldquoWith the new houses on their way, the town will need extra pharmacies and more GPs.ldquoIrsquom so disappointed that the pharmacy has been rejected, I really think we need one.

title: matt-kuchar-among-four-players-tied-scottish-open-lead-first-day
story: Kuchar shot an eight-under-par  in todays first round, leaving him tied with Frenchman Romain Wattel and Italian duo Edoardo Molinari and Nino Bertasio.Other big names who impressed were Swedens Henrik Stenton and Englishman Ian Poulter, who finished two shots behind the leaders, as did Richie Ramsay, who is the top-placed Scot after the first round.East Lothians Grant Forrest also had a fine showing, finishing with a four-under-par , the same total as four-time Major winner Rory McIlroy.Former Dunbar Grammar School pupil David Drysdale finished a shot further back but it also in good shape to make the cut with a similar round in tomorrows second day of play.

title: pictures-regiment-receives-historic-honour-parading-dunbar
story: Members of the public lined the streets in Dunbar on Saturday as a special presentation and parade took place to mark the historic moment involving the Lothians and Border Yeomanry.The regimentrsquos links with East Lothian date back to  with the formation of the East Lothian Yeomanry Cavalry.The Dunbar, Seton, Salton and Gford troops eventually disbanded and joined with other areas before reforming in  under the current name.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, East Lothian Councilrsquos Armed Forces Champion, conferred the Freedom of East Lothian to the Yeomanry, represented by Major Stuart Vine, in the shadow of Lauderdale House, the Regimentrsquos original home.Mr Goodfellow, who represents the North Berwick Coastal ward, said: ldquoAs well as being a landmark building on Dunbarrsquos High Street, Lauderdale House is the historic home of the Lothians and Border Yeomanry.ldquoIt is therefore appropriate that we are celebrating this occasion here in its shadow.ldquoThe Freedom of East Lothian is the highest honour our council can award.ldquoIt recognises those who play an important role here: those who represent our county and its values, contribute to the fabric of our civic society or who are integral to the history and tradition of East Lothian.ldquoIn granting the Freedom to the Lothians and Border Yeomanry today, the Regiment joins the Royal Scots Borderers st Battalion, renowned artist John Bellany and golf champion Catriona Matthew as worthy recipients of this rarely-bestowed tribute.ldquoLast weekend, our nation came together to commemorate Armed Services Day, which marks the important part that the Armed Services have played, and continue to play, in our society.ldquoToday we come together as a county to pay our particular thanks to the members of the Lothians and Border Yeomanry for the part it has played in East Lothian since its earliest roots as the East Lothian Yeomanry Cavalry in .ldquoIt is extraordinary to think that the regiment has represented East Lothian in every conflict since the Napoleonic Wars, including the Great War.Following the presentation, the regiment paraded along Dunbarrsquos High Street, saluting Mr Goodfellow outside the Town House, before continuing on to its war memorial outside Dunbar Parish Church on the townrsquos Queenrsquos Road for a rededication ceremony.Representatives from the council, serving and veteran members of the Armed Services community and their families, support organisations and crowds of well-wishers witnessed the occasion.Granting the Freedom of East Lothian to the regiment recognises the sacrices and service made by its members over the years, and reinforces the councilrsquos commitment to all armed services members living within the county.Major SJ Vine, Squadron Leader, ESquadron, The Scottish and North Irish Yeomanry, said the squadron was ldquotruly honoured to be given the Freedom of East Lothian.He added: ldquoThe day marks the reinvigoration of the strong partnership between the community and the squadron from which many of those serving, have served or represented through our long history and antecedent regiments live and work ndash we are grateful for the enduring support.ldquoIt is signicant and fitting that we are able to parade through Dunbar and also rededicate the war memorial in what is our spiritual home.ldquo[It was] a truly proud and memorable day and one which reconnects the lsquoCountyrsquos Regimentrsquo with the community whom we serve.The presentation and parade were part of a day of celebration of the regiment and Armed Services held in the town.A civic reception was held at the Town House for the Yeomanry and its supporters where a framed lsquoFreedom of East Lothianrsquo certicate was presented.The British Legion hosted a family event at its club for  people, while Dunbar Museum hosted a special one-day exhibition of the Yeomanryrsquos military treasures.

title: car-submerged-tide-north-berwick-beach
story: The incident, which took place on Sunday, required the assistance of the townrsquos RNLI, who had to tow the car out using their leboat tractor.The incident attracted plenty of attention, with many people stopping to take a look at the car being recovered.Eyewitness Derek Braid said: ldquoThe problem started when the owner of the car was recovering a RIB from the sea.ldquoThe car became stuck on the soft sand on the beach at the West Bay and the incoming tide engulfed the car.When the RNLI arrived, crew members attached a rope from the tractor to the car.After a number of attempts and plenty of pushing by the leboat crew and the other people nearby, the car was eventually successfully towed out of the water and taken to safety on the Elcho Green slipway.

title: degree-delight-ex-leuchie-chief
story: Mairi OrsquoKeefe was awarded a lsquoDegree of Doctor of the University, Honoris Causarsquo at a graduation ceremony in the Usher Hall in Edinburgh on Tuesday.She celebrated alongside Prue Leith, The Great British Bake Off judge and chancellor at Musselburgh-based QMU.Mairi is the former chief executive of Leuchie House, a respite care centre near North Berwick that provides care for those suffering from long-term neurological conditions and their families.She took over the helm at Leuchie in  when it was operated by the MS Society however, this was not her first experience in management as she has held ious airport manager and change manager roles.She helped save the centre from closure in  after setting up the lsquoSave Leuchiersquo campaign and building support for the centre.The campaign gained enough backing to allow Leuchie to become an independent charity.Over the next seven years, Mairi and her team secured pound. million in grants from trust funds and donations from members of the public, as well as support from the Scottish Government, delivering more than , respite nights.Mairi sat on cross-party groups in the Scottish Parliament, was vice-chair of the Health and Social Alliance Scotland and a member of the Governing Council for Edinburgh Chamber of Commerce.In  she was awarded lsquoCommunity Champion of the yearrsquo in STVrsquos lsquoFinding Scotlandrsquos Real Heroesrsquo awards. Two years later, she received an MBE for services to people with disabilities.Mairi has helped establish an official partnership with QMU, which has been in place since . The partnership has allowed for clinical and work placements, research and creative opportunities to be provided to many students, including nurses, film students, dietetics, physiotherapy and gastronomy.Mairi announced her retirement last year.Professor Petra Wend, principal and vice-chancellor of QMU, said: ldquoWe are delighted that our students had the opportunity to learn about the career of this former nursing and social care leader and to be inspired by her achievements and her compassion for others.ldquoWe are proud to recognise Mairi as a hard-working advocate for people living with disabilities across Scotland and beyond.ldquoWe celebrated her achievements as a leader and her success in integrating healthcare with respite services.

title: schoolteacher-recreates-law-primary-school-lego
story: The P pupils were invited to make their own creations to join supply teacher Malcolm Piriersquos recreation of the primary school at the Awesome Bricks event as it took pride of place at the title: construction-work-waste-incinerator-near-dunbar-now-complete
story: Final tests are being carried out at the energy recovery facilityat Oxwellmains, with low-carbon energy already being generated at the site, to the south-west of Dunbar.The completion of Viridorrsquos ERF marks the latest milestone in a project delivering a , tonne per year energy recovery facility to Scotland.A key part of the poundm investment by Viridor in Scotland, the ERF will ert non-recyclable waste from landfill in line with the Scottish Governmentrsquos ambitions and contribute to Scottish energy security.More than  contractors put in more than two-million man hours to the project, with more than  workers on site at its peak.Scott Reynolds, Dunbar ERF operations manager, said that the site had already started generating low-carbon energy for the national grid and, over the course of the coming year, would create MW of base-load low-carbon energy direct to the electricity grid.The energy generated ndash which, according to Viridor, is comparable to  wind turbines ndash is enough to continuously power , homes.Mr Reynolds said: ldquoViridor is pleased to be working with the Scottish local authorities and businesses to put non-recyclable waste to work.ldquoWith the construction phase of the project now complete, we are carrying out final plant testing as we process non-recyclable waste, using this as the fuel to create electricity.ldquoThe new facility includes a visitorsrsquo centre, where we look forward to welcoming interested groups to encourage the next generation to put the right stuff in the right bin.ldquoWe will be talking about recycling here at the plant because we want to ensure valuable recycling opportunities are not missed.ldquoThe waste which comes here should only be waste which cannot be recycled, allowing us to attach a purpose to it through energy recovery.The plant is constructed on , piles, or vertical foundations, upon which sit more than , tonnes of concrete and steel to support the processing equipment of the -metre-high building.The facility features two boilers, each processing  tonnes of waste each hour, and managed and controlled through km of pipework and km of cabling.Waste received at Dunbar ERF will include residual household waste from East Lothian Council, as well as the local authorities in North and South Lanarkshire, in addition to non-recyclable commercial collections from Edinburgh and the Lothians.

title: big-yins-greatest-ever-comedy-routines-published-first-time
story: The comic has agreed a deal with a publisher for a new book called Tall Tales And Wee Stories which will feature classic yarns such as The Last Supper, Jojoba Shampoo, Incontinence Pants and Shouting at Wildebeest.Despite a -year stand-up career, the stories he tells on stage have not previously been released in written form.The book will be published in October by Two Roads.It comes after the Big Yin, who is suffering from Parkinsonrsquos disease, announced his retirement from stand-up last December.:Sir Billy Connolly chants with Glaswegians in New YorkConnolly, , will be writing a new introduction for the book, which will be illustrated by his artwork.He said: ldquoI was a storyteller long before I was a comedian. Coming from Glasgow, itrsquos weird, I donrsquot really tell jokes, like Irish jokes and all that, I tell wee stories.ldquoIrsquove been asked many times to put them down in a book and Irsquove always refused.ldquoIt didnrsquot seem right because as long as I was still performing live then I was still playing around with my stories ndash pulling them apart, twisting them around, improvising and improving.ldquoBut in December of last year, I decided to retire from live stand-up. So, this feels like the right moment to put these stories down, once and for all. Itrsquos always been a pleasure talking to you. I hope now itrsquoll be a pleasure reading me.The blurb for the book reads: ldquoBillyrsquos routines always felt spontaneous. He improvised, embellished and digressed as he went: a two-minute anecdote could become a -minute routine by the next night of a tour. And he brought a beautul sense of the absurd to his shows as he rfed on holidays, alcohol, the crucixion, or naked bungee jumping.For all your breaking Glasgow news, click here, or head to our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pagesldquoBut Billyrsquos comedy could be laced with anger too. He hated pretentiousness and called out hypocrisy where ever he saw it.ldquoHe loved to shock, and his startling appearance gave him license to say anything he damn well pleased about sex, politics or religion. It was only because he was so likeable that he got it away. Billy had the popular touch. His comedy spanned generations and dferent social tribes in a way that few others have ever managed.Nick Davies, managing director at John Murray Press who acquired the rights for publishing house Two Roads, said: ldquoAs his many millions of fans will know, Billyrsquos stories can be rude, warm-hearted, anarchic, joyful, angry, far-fetched, down-to-earth and everything in between.ldquoThey are also beautully constructed, brilliantly paced and deeply funny.

title: cycling-golf-football-cricket-hockey-scottish-women-going-glory-home-soil
story: They each clutch assorted implements: a football, a hockey stick, a cricket bat, golf clubs and a bicycle.Among their number is golfing legend Catriona Matthew, Olympic champion cyclist Katie Archibald and rising football star Michaela McAlonie. Theres also the cricketer Samantha Haggo and hockey player Becky Ward, who between them have close to  international caps.They are here to celebrate what is being dubbed as a "Summer of Womens Sport" with Scotland gearing up to host six European and world-class events over the next three months, beginning with the UEFA European Womens Under- Championship on Tuesday.The tournament, which runs until July , will act as a qualier for the  FIFA Under- Womens World Cup. Scotland will play its first match against France at St Mirren Park, Paisley, on Tuesday evening.The Womens EuroHockey Championship II takes place in Glasgow from August - followed by the inaugural Womens Tour of Scotland cycling event between August -, traversing Dundee to Dunfermline, Glasgow to Perth and Edinburgh via the Scottish Borders in three race stages.Next up is golf: the Aberdeen Standard Investments Ladies Scottish Open tees up from August - at The Renaissance Club in North Berwick. Then it is the turn of cricket with the ICC Womens T World Cup Global Qualier in Dundee and Angus from August  to September .Rounding it off will be the Solheim Cup, the biennial golf tournament contested by teams from Europe and the US, with around , spectators expected to converge on Gleneagles from September -.To mark this packed calendar, VisitScotland and EventScotland has launched a promotional campaign #sportingsisters aimed at getting fans along to enjoy the action. Here we meet some of the sportswomen hoping to dazzle on home soil.KATIE ARCHIBALD, , CYCLISTThe reigning Olympic and Commonwealth Games champion got her start racing on Highland grass tracks as a teenager. Archibald, from Milngavie, is a multiple world and European gold medallist. She is the ambassador for the Womens Tour of Scotland.How did you fall in love with sport Trying to be as good as my older brother John. Thats what sport has ended up meaning to me: competition. I know it doesnt mean that for everyone, but I love to race and compete. It is rivalry that made me fall in love with sport.Why cycling For a long time, cycling was the way that I got to other sports. I would ride my bike to the hockey club and swimming pool. It was about holidays and being with my family because it is such a social sport. We would go out riding together and cycle touring meant I got to see a lot of the world.It wasnt until I was a teenager that I combined the two passions of riding a bike and entering races. I started competing through the Highland Games grass track racing. There was a handicap, which meant I got a big head start and a taste for winning very quickly.Career high Winning gold at the  Rio Olympic Games.Career low Im a bit of a misery guts, so I am always convinced that the most recent race was my worst. I will moan to people, saying: "Im going terribly".Most sportspeople have an anecdote of when they went against the odds with an injury or setback. You almost cant prosper without these things. For me, it was tearing my PCL [posterior cruciate ligament] in my knee [in a motorcycle accident] back in .It was Christmas time and eight months before the Olympic Games. You start thinking that it is all going to slip away from you.What are the biggest misconceptions about what you do That sportspeople are motivated all the time. Im guilty of looking around my teammates or rivals and thinking that I will be caught out as a fraud and cant possibly be training as hard as they are.: Paul McCartney on his love of Scotland and the exhibition of hislate we Lindas photography in GlasgowMy dad jokes about how I dont have a job and Ill say: "But my job is  . I have to look after my body all the time." We say these things and I guess little kids probably believe it, that every breath I breathe is with the ambition of getting a step closer to Tokyo .They believe it because I say it and I want it to be true, but human beings dont work that way. I do wake up and want to go straight back to bed a lot of the time.What do you enjoy most Going fast and the thrill of racing.Will you be taking part in the Womens Tour of Scotland We are going to be entering a Scottish national team which is cool because it is usually only once every four years for the Commonwealth Games that we get to wear our Scotland kit. What is brilliant about road racing is you can turn up at the roadside and see world-class cycling for free.Dream dinner party guests Caitlin Moran, David Mitchell and Scroobius Pip.What are your passions away from sport Eating cake in nice cafes.Visit womenstourofscotlandCATRIONA MATTHEW, , GOLFERAs Scotlands top women player over the past  years, North Berwick-based Matthew won the Womens British Open in  and is a two-time winner of the Ladies Scottish Open. She is the European captain for the Solheim Cup.How did you fall in love with sport I was always a bit of a tomboy growing up and trying to keep up with my two older brothers. I was fortunate my parents got me into all dferent sports: golf, badminton, tennis and hockey.Career high Winning the Womens British Open in .Career low I wouldnt say I have one. I tend to only think about the highs.What are the biggest misconceptions about what you do Peoples perception of le on tour. They think you are going to all these exotic places around the world where you are on holiday and get to sightsee, whereas you are golfing and working.What do you enjoy most The competition. When you get to the top at a sport, you are very competitive. It is the competition I have enjoyed most and testing myself against the best players in the world.:Summer Reads  ndash the best beach and holiday booksAre you looking forward to the Solheim Cup It has been a big part of my career over the last  years so having the opportunity to captain it in Scotland is a dream come true. Looking at the players, myself and the vice-captain, seeing how everyone is playing, the team is beginning to take shape and it is exciting.Who was your childhood hero I dont knowI really had one. There wasnt much ladies golf on television at that point. It was the era of Sandy Lyle, Seve [Ballesteros], [Jose Maria] Olazabal, [Ian] Woosnam and [Nick] Faldo. I grew up watching those players.You play all over the world. Is it exciting to showcase Scotland to golf fans Ive had numerous people phoning, trying to seeI can get them on dferent golf courses around the country. Some people are wanting to go walking on the west coast, others are coming over to try and play a bit of golf beforehand and making a whole trip of the week.What are your passions away from sport Ive not got many passions away from sport. I love sport and watch all kinds of sport. I think my kids get a bit fed up because there is always sport on our TV.Whats the best advice you have been given Be yourself and dont worry what other people think.Visit ladiesscottishopen and solheimcupMICHAELA MCALONIE, , FOOTBALLERA defender with  caps at under- level, McAlonie from Edinburgh has a wealth of experience having played with Heart of Midlothian Women FC and Spartans FC Women. She is part of the Scotland squad for the UEFA European Womens Under- Championship.How did you fall in love with sport I have always been a competitive and sporty person. I got into football because I saw the boys playing it at lunchtime in high school. I ended up going for a trial with the after-school team because it was mixed with boys and girls.I was scouted to go to Hutchison Vale Girls and played there for a year. Then I was scouted to go to Hearts and was brought up into the first team when I was . It was good playing at that level. I joined Spartans in .I have left school and as well as playing football I work at Spartans doing the cafe. Im going to college in August to study health, fitness and exercise.Career high Playing for my country. It is such an honour. My first game for Scotland at under-s was against Germany.How do you feel about playing on home turf at the Under- Euros Im excited. It will be great having family and friends come to watch as its hard for them to travel abroad. Im looking forward to it because it will challenge us as a team and inidually.Who was your childhood hero My grandad was a big part of my football le when I was growing up. Travelling takes up a lot of time and he was there to help with that. He motivates me to want to play the best I can.: Paul McCartney on his love of Scotland and the exhibition of hislate we Lindas photography in GlasgowSomeone I look up to is Scotland footballer Erin Cuthbert. She is not much older than me and played in the World Cup. Claire Emslie who scored against England too.Do you have a motto If its meant to be, its up to me.Dream dinner party guests My grandad  I have dinner with him all the time. Will Smith and his son Jaden.What are your passions away from sport Singing. Im not any good at it, but in the changing room I like to dance and sing.Do you have a favourite Scottish football location Im a Hearts fan so it would have to be Gorgie.Visit scotfa.co ourgirlsourgame and uefa womensunder BECKY WARD, , HOCKEY PLAYERThe Glasgow-based PE teacher, originally from Dundee, is a stalwart of the international hockey scene. Becky Ward has competed for Scotland at two Commonwealth Games ndash Glasgow  and Gold Coast  ndash and has  caps. She plays for Western Wildcats Hockey Club.How did you fall in love with sport I did a bit of everything when I was younger: swimming, football and gymnastics. My auntie was part of the local hockey club and got me involved. I found that I preferred the team element of hockey to swimming. I was about eight when I started hockey.Career high Competing at Glasgow . The home support was incredible. Playing in the Scotland vs England match was special.Career low I have been lucky in terms of injuries. Probably the biggest low was missing out on selection for the top-flight Europeans in .What do you enjoy most Playing as part of a team. Hockey has taken me to some cool places around the world.Biggest misconceptions I think people underestimate it. Hockey is such an exciting game. The skill level and fitness required make it impressive to watch.Do you have a nickname Wardy or Wardie. Thats the team debate: is it an Y or an IE :Summer Reads  ndash the best beach and holiday booksWho was your childhood hero Im a big ice hockey fan and my heroes are the  USA Olympic ice hockey team. The team they sent to the Olympics was a mix of college hockey players who won gold. I find that story inspiring.Are you looking forward to the Womens EuroHockey Championship II It is home soil and you cant ask for much better than that. Being back on the pitch where we competed in Glasgow  will be special.What are your passions away from competing Im an ice hockey fan. I support the Dundee Stars. I like to go watch them playI am not busy training or competing. Im also a big movie fan.Dream dinner party guests Sir David Attenborough, Queen Victoria and Prince Albert, Freddie Mercury and Led Zeppelin.Visit scottish-hockey.org.ukSAMANTHA HAGGO, , CRICKETERSamantha Haggo hails from a cricketing family: her uncle David Haggo was a wicketkeeper for Scotland and her father Allan Haggo is an international umpire. The Edinburgh-based player, originally from Prestwick, has gained  caps. Her day job is working for Judo Scotland.How did you fall in love with sport Cricket is ingrained in my family. I couldnt avoid it and luckily got the love for it as well. Im a big football fan and used to play tennis. Sport has been there from the start.Career high Reaching  caps. When I was  and asked what I wanted to do when I grew up, I said I wanted to play cricket for Scotland. My th cap was a special moment because it showed I had reached that pinnacle.Career low I broke my finger in the warm-ups of the World Cup qualier in Colombo in . I was ruled out of the tournament. I had been training so hard for it all winter. That was a low point.What are the biggest misconceptions about what you do That cricket is boring and there is a lot of standing around. It is an incredibly exciting sport. There is so much going on from the tactical elements to the unbelievable athleticism cricketers need to pull off a ing catch or hit a huge six.What do you enjoy most Im a bowler and I love the battle you have with the batter. You have six bowls each over and that is six opportunities to try and outsmart them and get their wicket. I love fielding and trying to take a spectacular catch.Do you have a nickname I have probably the most nicknames of anyone in the world. My main one isnt very PG. Its "Shaggo" because my name is S Haggo. I also get called "Haggis".Who do you most admire Dame Katherine Grainger. She came second at the Olympics three times and then finally won gold. I met her at a sporting event a few years ago. Her story has stuck with me through tough times. If you put the hard yards in, you will be rewarded for it.Do you have a motto Never give up. I have always had a fire in my belly and a positive mental attitude.What are your passions away from sport Ive recently started a new job in communications and marketing at Judo Scotland. That is exciting and Im enjoying it. I love being outdoors and exploring Edinburghs brunch spots in my spare time. My other big passions are musical theatre and yoga.: Paul McCartney on his love of Scotland and the exhibition of hislate we Lindas photography in GlasgowWhat are you looking forward to about the ICC Womens T World Cup Global Qualier The fact we have a home advantage. A lot of people rely on social media to follow our games wherever we are in the world, so it will be nice to have them come along to watch and hopefully challenge the misconceptions that womens sport and cricket are boring.Visit cricketscotland

title: lewis-capaldi-vs-noel-gallagher
story: Itrsquos not the first time the pair have clashed with Gallagher calling Capaldirsquos music ldquof*****g w***k in a radio interview in June before the cheeky Scot entertained his fans ndash and won many more ndash by swaggering onto Glastonburyrsquos Other Stage wearing a T-shirt emblazoned with the older Gallagher brotherrsquos face.Lewis, who Lewis Capaldi was born in Glasgow and brought up in Whitburn, West Lothian. He released his debut EP in  and soon rose to the top of the charts with heartbreak ballad, Someone You Loved.The -year-old learned to play the guitar when he was nine-years-old and has been touring pubs since he was .The floppy-haired Scot is related to Doctor Who star Peter Capaldi who starred in the heart-string-tugging video for his number one hit.The younger Capaldi is known for his irreverent sense of humor as well as his music. He regularly pokes good-humoured fun at himself and others on social media and has won lots of fans for not taking himself too seriously.He declared himself the lsquoScottish Beyoncersquo ahead of the launch of his debut album, Divinely Inspired to a Hellish Extent, and he stars in his own television adverts where he says: ldquoIf you like chubby guys singing sad songs, yoursquore in for an absolute treat.So whatrsquos the beef with Noel Gallagher In June, Gallagher gave an interview to Radio X, a UK radio station, where he called Capaldirsquos music ldquof*****g w***k, before singling out the Scottish singer saying ldquoWhorsquos this Capaldi fella  Who the f*** is that idiot Rather than weep into his cornflakes, Capaldi took the abuse in good spirits, striding onto the stage at Glastonbury wearing a bucket hat and khaki parks in a nod to Oasis, before revealing his T-shirt that bore Gallagherrsquos face inside a heart.: Irn-Bru cancel Noel Gallagher after he brands Scotland a third world countryThe crowd went wild and after his set Capaldi told Jo Whiley on Radio : ldquoNoel brought me up in an interview the other day and said he wasnrsquot the biggest fan of the music.ldquoIrsquom a huge fan of his so I thought the only way to do my first ever Glastonbury, would be to pay homage to a man who I love so dearly.ldquoHersquos almost like a spiritual fatheryou will, so I had the parka, the bucket hat, the whole thing. I hope he sees it, I love him to bits.Capaldi was later photographed with Noelrsquos brother and arch rival Liam at the music festival, stirring the spat up further.Why doesnrsquot Noel pick on someone his own size No stranger to a feud, it could be said that the High Flying Birds singer doesnrsquot know when to leave well alone.In an interview with Variety magazine, h said Scotland - the country his we Sara hails from - ldquois like a third world country.He also compared Capaldi to the Star Wars character Chewbacca and told him to ldquoenjoy his  minutes of fame.Capaldi promptly posted a photoshopped picture of his face onto the Wookieersquos body and changed his Twitter handle to Chewis Capaldi.Gallagher said: ldquoThe greatest day of his le that I slagged him off or called him an idiot.ldquoItrsquos the greatest day of his f****** le so far. Hersquos just thinking lsquowowrsquo.ldquoWell, I know yoursquore Scottish and all that but f****** hell. Surely.Gallagherrsquos daughter Anais weighed in, writing on social media: ldquoI want to be Lewis Capaldi when I grow up.What happened next Liam Gallagher weighed on to defend Capaldi by revealing he ldquof*****g adores Scotland on social media in a post that was shared widely.:Liam Gallagher weighs in on Noels third world country commentsScotlandrsquos self-declared national fizzy drink, Irn Bru then announced that it had ldquocancelled Noel after his comments about Scotland. title: future-shock-ann-widdecombe-joyous-orange-order-march-proves-unionism-way-free-scotland-oppression
story: Of course, I remain humbly grateful for my new role as Brexit Party envoy for the ruling Monarch. And especially proud to represent all loyalists who serve her ndash even foul-mouthed Scotch police officers. I am, as you may know, referring to a particularly distasteful incident which took place in Glasgow last Saturday ndash which I believe has ldquogone viral on social media ndash where an unsavoury word many conflate with Jeremy Hunt was heard emanating from the mouth of a unormed officer, prefixed by the query ldquoAre you coming the.I will always defend those who themselves defend the Crown, no matter what distant region of Albion they hail from. So when Police Scotland officers employ Anglo-Saxon colloquialisms in the course ofduty, I must always assume it has been a wholly justiable belittling of female genitalia.The officerrsquos inquiry had apparently been deployed to ascertain the character of one particularly disruptive inidual ndash who was scurrilously attempting to spoil the buoyant mood of a glorious loyalist parade by blasting ldquorebel music from his car. How he got so close to these patriotic footsoldiers and joy-fuelled revellers with all the city-centre roads closed off, surrounded by motorway tailbacks, I have no idea. A truly disruptive person indeed.On these thankfully rare occasions, when officers of the law cross the line and let vile sexual crudities slip, I believe we must put our shock to one side and attempt to understand the context of such outbursts. And, as always, it seems all blame can be directed towardsthe fractured and Godless nature of todayrsquos society, where indference toine retribution has led to standards of the Queenrsquos English falling lower than the groin glands of the snake in the Garden of Eden.Itrsquos a truly sad day when the only way a dutul servant of Her Majesty can impose their authority is to attempt communicationwith these primitive creatures in their native tongue.The ides of marchDespite thisdisruption, it was wholly invigorating to witness so many of Her Majestyrsquos loyal defenders stride valiantly and gallantly through the city streets, glorying the Union as their ominous tribal thump echoed around the so-called Dear Green Place!It certainly filled my heart with optimism for the nationrsquos future.There were only eight arrests and apart from that, all more or less passed without incident. Unless you count jubilant cheering from the masses lining the route as a breach of the peace! Or the woman fallingfoul of the strictly-observed ldquodonrsquot cross the march rule who was shoved and spat on, butshe should perhapsbe grateful tohave DNA for any forthcoming trial. At least it wasnrsquot a Catholic priest this year!Although there was a distinct lack of reportage on this exhuberantannual celebration in the mainstream media ndash even in the so-called unionist press ndash I can confirm this was a rousing, joyous, inclusive, family parade. This was evident in the child-friendly aesthetic of Disney-like toy soldier unorms, comedygoose-stepping and Les Dawson-style musical timing ndash performed by men all clearly in robust health despite their advanced years, with the beetroot hue on their faces indicative of a burning internalpassion.Indeed, the jubilant onlookers could have lit cigarettes off the marchersrsquocheeksthey had so wished, an act perhapssymbolicof the undying torchflameof unionist fervourpassed on through countlessfuture generations.On evidence of this annual celebration of inherited reality tunnels, it will surely not be long until Orangefest ndash first and last held in  ndash makes a triumphantto George Square. Although the bouncy castle and marquees couldnrsquot be erected last time due to a freakishly unseasonal ill wind on the day, the children were still ldquoblown away by the informative speakers and stirring history lessons-highlightingthe truefacts on our nationrsquos history thatthey willhopefullypass onto their ownoffspringone day. And surely even the most staunch republican has to admit Orangefest had a better line-up than this yearrsquosTRNSMT.Out of OrderMY hopes that this mass display of Scotch support for peace, harmony and the Union might signal the end of the countryrsquos binarytribalism soon soured, however. It came to my attention that on the same day, , members of the republican McCult were congregating to insult Her Majesty by marching upon the Royal Burgh of Ayr ndash despite being firmly told five years ago that their shortbread tin cos-play had been cancelled by popular demand!Languidly marching ldquoAll Under One Banner, this flag-waving rabble would apparently prefertheir chainsattached to the EU rather than England ndash clearly ignorant to how it was the mighty Union itself that elevated their beloved Ayr to global glory!The  Act opened up trading opportunities with our colonies across the seas, resulting in myriad improvements to the town and lting its global standing. Ayrrsquos textile, wool, linen and shoemaking industries thrived for centuries afterwards. Crown funding provided by the Convention of Royal Burghs led to a lighthouse being built on the River Ayr in , a quay in  and also paid for much-needed repairs to the harbour and High Tolbooth. The CRB then installed street lighting for all ndash but little did they know that  years later a shameful display of open rebellion would cast the town back to the dark ages!After the procession in Glasgow, it was no surprise to hear that one of these so-called Bravehearts ndash many sporting battle re-enactment outfitsndash ended up on social media spouting a crude torrent of foul language, accusing a small gathering of pro-unionists of being female genitalia with unionist affiliations.And unlike the Orange Order, who have always worked closely with the council and police, the AUOB organisers apparently refused to apply for a licence or take out public liability insurance, claiming their ldquopeaceful rallies havenrsquot experienced any issues that required such legalities! Clearly then, it is somehow perfectly acceptable for nationalists to shout loudly about womenrsquos genitals in Ayr ndash but heaven forbid you are a loyal servant of Her Majesty doing the same thing in Glasgow while simply trying to maintain Order!And finally...YOU might be aware of yet another march that took place on the same day ndash Pridein London. I hadnrsquot seen so many men in leather masks living out their submissive fantasies since my time in the Conservative party.With . millionin attendance, one couldnrsquot get moving in the capital that day ndash yet such a commotion could perhaps have been avoidedmy previous solution of conversion therapy to tackle ldquounhappy homosexuality had been heeded.I once wrote: ldquoIf anybody turns to a properly qualied practitioner for help, there must be a presumption that he or she can get it. It is not a state crime to want to change onersquos sexual leanings. It still isnrsquot! And there will also perhaps be room to move in the streets on Pride dayscience finds the answer to the issue, like I said last week.Irsquove previously admitted that I am proud to remain a virgin, and although some might suggest this disqualies me from commenting on the sexual lives of others, remember it certainly doesnrsquot stop the Pope! And having converted to Catholicism from the Church of England some years ago , I have to say it may now be time to organise my own minority march ndash for Catholics who support Her Majesty and the Union!

title: joanna-blythman-226-gallowgate-marches-tune-eschewing-copycat-menus-simple-unfussy-forgotten-classics
story: Itrsquos saddening to see such a landmark in Glasgowrsquos fascinating East End architecture and history left in such a parlous state. Is it the thin end of a wedge  Municipal neglect has a habit of creeping outwards like a bad stain.And so wersquore heartened to see some benign citizen development up on the Gallowgate at the old Bairdrsquos Bar next door to Barrowland. This is the cleverest, the most respectful of renovations. Residues of Celtic green paint cling to the ceiling. The materials- dark wood , brick, sandstone, clunking Victorian iron, obscure glass- encapsulate Glasgowrsquos vernacular architecture for me. Whatever was sound has been kept along with the odd bit of evocative whimsy. The old tenement stairs that now lead to nowhere have been kept above the bar. You pass a deep ceramic sink for washing clothes, the sort that was once commonplace in old ldquosteamies". Such artacts are on display at the Peoplersquos Palace, and  Gallowgate only adds to the collection.In other ways  Gallowgate marches to its own tune, eschewing copycat menus. Its offering manages to be original, yet it fits its setting and location: simple, unfussy dishes, forgotten classics, such as corned beef hash, at reasonable prices that are realistic for its neighbourhood.Everything that reasonably can be is made in the kitchen, apart from the sourdough bread from the Freedom Bakery, and only ace bakers could better that. But the kitchen cures its own salt beef, we discover, as we kick off with the meaty, peppery salt beef fritters perched on frills of amiably mild sauerkraut, napped by punchy Reuben sauce and melting cheese.  Gallowgate clearly isnrsquot immune to cooking trends though. On todayrsquos specials menu therersquos caullower, pale-roasted, in a tumble of mint leaves, pea shoots, soft soaked raisins, toasted pine kernels, and grated Manchego cheese with perhaps a bit of sherry vinegar in its dressing, an idea I intend to steal for home cooking purposes.Boiled gammon and buttered cabbage with spring onion mash  Itrsquos got to be well done, or itrsquos dull. But this ham is a dream, not too salty, with a pale pink blush, it disintegrates in the mouth. The scallions, and a generous dosage of butter, make the mash unctuous the cabbage, Savoy Irsquod say, glistens with even more butter. No complaints from me on that last point.For pound, our hot salt beef sandwich is a steal. Our second chance to taste the succulent, well balanced cured beef, to appreciate just how well that Freedom Bakery bread with its tangible, but not overly chewy, crust works brilliantly in this context. Pickled cucumber spikes the meat and bread with vinegary sharpness while creamy horseradish lubricates it. Out of curiosity we have ordered a side of vinegar peas, another historical homage: back in the day they used to be sold to the Barrowland crowds from a whole in the wall eatery next door. Actually, these are broad beans, and a couple is enough for me, but they come with more sourdough and a pat of French butter. For pound, wersquore not complaining.Our servers are jolly and their enthusiasm for the deep fried custard, which turns out to be more like a doughnut with a custard core, is infectious. But wersquore more smitten with the rhubarb and ginger crumble, its deep layer of stem ginger-spiked fruit, its knobbly, crunchy topping.The people who opened  Gallowgate seem to get old Glasgow, its mood, its character, it value. Herersquos hoping that a similar respect for heritage and culture colonises the City Chambers. Gallowgate, Glasgow   Food:  and a half Atmosphere:  Service:  Value for money:  Joanna BlythmanGuild of Food Writers Food Writer of the Year

title: scotland-39-s-proud-history-castles---now-one-spare-3m
story: Eilean Donan, at Dornie by the Kyle of Lochalsh, is unmistakable, with the narrow footbridge leading to the castle on the water where three sea lochs meet, with the Cuillins of Skye in the far distance. It has featured in films like Bonnie Prince Charlie, with the unlikely David Niven in the role in , The Master of Ballantrae with Erroll Flynn , Highlander and even the Bond movie The World is not enough. Itrsquos a staple of dozens of Bollywood movies too, soyoursquore visiting and see a group of dancers in brightly-coloured dhoti practising their steps yoursquove come to the right place.The castle was a stronghold of the Clans Mackenzie and McRae from the th Century before it was destroyed, in , by the Royal Navy in the Jacobite rebellion. Three ships anchored up and bombarded the castle and the clansmen and their Spanish allies for three days, reducing the place to rubble and taking dozens of prisoners. It lay as an empty ruin for more than  years until John MacRae-Gilstrap bought the pile in  and set about restoring it. So what you see today is a modern-day rendition although, fortunately, sans breeze blocks and polystyrene. It is now owned by a charitable MacRae family trust and the , visitors a year undoubtedly provide the upkeep.Scotland surely must have more castles per acre than any other country, and certainly per head of population, with around  and counting ndash more than the population of Aberfeldy or Drumnadrochit ndash although some are no more than relics of the past, hardly a stone upon a stone. Therersquos not agreed definition of a castle ndash every Englishmanrsquos home is one after all ndash but itrsquos generally accepted that it has to be a fortied structure built in the Middle Agesby a ruler or noble. One who was generally carnapcious, didnrsquot get on with his neighbours and had hundreds of serfs of clans people to provide the wherewithal, a bit like Historic Environment Scotland today.The latest castle to come up for private sale is Bardowie, eight miles from Glasgow, an A-listed, eight-bedroomed property with a walled garden, tennis court, jetty and frontage to the eponymous loch, which is a mere puddle in water terms. It was built in  and was a stronghold of the Galbraiths and passed on to the Hamiltonrsquos of Bardowie.Its more recent history is that it was owned by Jack Black ndash not the Rock School star or it would be no more than sandstone dust now ndash but the other one, the one who charges thousands to make motivational speeches. He used to be a social worker in Glasgowrsquos East End so he must wake up every day, even before he makes up a pithy epithet, to thank his lord he escaped the snotty weans and junkies.To quote the guru: ldquoThe greatest gt in le is the ability to think great thoughts and have the strength to take action so that those thoughts become reality in this wonderful and abundant world.Er, moving on it seems that Jack sold the castle at the end of  and the present owner is Glasgow vegetable dealer Alex Faithfullthrough his company Bardowie Holdings. He certainly lives there, unless he flitted very recently. The castle is now on the market for around pound million although the agents arenrsquot confirming the price. .The Hollywood star Chris Pine stayed there for a couple of months at the end of  to get into the method for his role in Outlaw King, as Robert Bruce.Most of the surviving castles are either in public ownership or in charitable trusts. Edinburgh, Stirling and Culzean most famously, although exceptions are Inveraray Castle, the seat of the Dukes of Argyll and now a popular tourist attraction, Stobo Castle a health spa, and the quirky Kelburn, owned by Patrick Boyle, the th Earl of Glasgow ndash continuously occupied by the same family since the th century, longer than any other caste ndash who invited some famous Brazilian artist to graffiti the entire facade which, despite the sneers of the traditionalists, has become a tourist attractionCastles first arrived in Scotland in the th century as royal authority was centralised and rewards were doled out. It was King David  who introduced them and encouraged Norman and French nobles to settle here, in an attempt to establish royal power throughout the country.Robert the Bruce must also take credit,thatrsquos the proper term, for what became known as ldquoslighting, that is capturing castles and destroying their fortications, which he did systematically, after wresting them from English control and presumably slaughtering the survivors. He even destroyed his own ones, at Ayr and Dumfries, Roxburgh and Edinburgh rather than allow them to be retaken by the English.When gunpowder was invented and guns and cannons evolved in the th century the design of castles changed, to the look we expect today, bombardment resistant walls, letter box gun ports and s to mount artillery. Ravenscraig, in Kirkcaldy, begun in  and now partially ruined, is reckoned to be the first in Britain to be built as an artillery fort.If a castle isnrsquot quite your choice of residence and you are shopping at the top end of the market then what about Boraston House, in Ravelston Dykes Road, Edinburgh, which is a seven-bedroom Edwardian mansion house on the edge of Ravelston Golf Course. Offers over pound.m. Or a six-bedroomed terraced house in the New Town, four floors plus a roof terrace, at offers over pound.m.To the west there are a couple of places in Bothwell, one at Mill Road with five bedrooms and a price tag of pound.m and a huge and rather ugly looking mansion in Clydebrae Drive with a garden going down to the Clyde at pound.m.OrPerthshirersquos your choice therersquos a -bedroom, -bathroom Georgian mansion set in . acres of manicured grounds plus a two-bedroom cottage for the nanny, in Aberargie for just pound.m. And just  minutes from Inverness Airport, at Croy, you can pick up a Highland estate, Holme Rose, with gorgeous A-listed Georgian mansion, eight bedrooms, not forgetting the mile of salmon and trout fishing rights on the river Nairn, complete with cottages and  acres, eight miles from Nairn.
